questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

You have 500 corporate-owned Android devices enrolled as fully managed devices.

You need to prepare an app named App1 for deployment to the devices.

Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
I agree with given answer

B. Sync App1 with Intune:

This action ensures that App1 is synchronized with Intune, making it available for deployment to enrolled devices.
C. From the Managed Google Play Store, approve App1:

This action is necessary to approve App1 from the Managed Google Play Store so that it can be deployed to the enrolled Android devices via Intune.

Selected Answer: BC
I agree with given answer

Selected Answer: BC
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/apps-add-android-for-work

A: "From the Intune Company Portal, download App1": Incorrect. This would apply to installing apps on BYOD (Android Enterprise personally owned work profile devices), but the question specifies fully managed devices. Fully managed devices get their apps from the managed Google Play app store, not the intune company portal app.
D. "Create an OEM config profile": Incorrect. These profiles manage device settings not installing apps

Answer: B & C
https://www.anoopcnair.com/add-android-managed-google-play-app-in-intune/

ChatGPT: 
To prepare an app named App1 for deployment to the corporate-owned Android devices enrolled as fully managed devices in Microsoft Intune, you should perform the following actions:

B. Sync App1 with Intune.
C. From the Managed Google Play Store, approve App1.

Therefore, the correct actions are B and C.

Selected Answer: BC
CORRECT

Selected Answer: AC
Option B is not correct because syncing App1 with Intune is not required for app deployment.
Option D is not correct because an OEMConfig profile is used to configure device-specific settings, not app deployment.

choices.C: From the Managed Google Play Store, approve App1.
choices.A: From the Intune Company Portal, download App1.

choices.E: Device1, Device2, Device3, and Device4 only

questions.question_text:
You have the Windows 10 devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You plan to upgrade the devices to Windows 11 Enterprise.

On which devices can you perform a direct in-place upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise?

discussion.content: A, the key in the question is "perform a direct in-place upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise?" so with a Pro machine you need to then do an edition upgrade. This is why the suggested answer is A only the already Enterprise machine can be directly upgraded.

comments.content: If you use a Windows 11 Enterprise Subscription on a Windows 10 pro Device with 64bit, it performs an in-place upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise. Whereas on the Windows 11 Computer, it will just activate as the Enterprise edition. So I think you are right? Microsoft is really confusing with their wording

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
there is no DIRECT way for a Device 4 to in-place upgrade to Win 11 E: it would have to in-place upgrade to Win 11 Pro first, then activate the Enterprise license

Selected Answer: C
The correct choice is C. Device2, Device3, and Device4 only because these devices meet the requirements for a direct in-place upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise. To perform an in-place upgrade, the devices must have a compatible version of Windows 10 (such as Pro or Enterprise, version 2004 or later), meet the hardware requirements for Windows 11 (including a TPM 2.0 chip, Secure Boot, at least 4 GB of RAM, 64 GB of storage, and a supported 64-bit processor), and already run an edition that allows an upgrade to Enterprise. Device1 does not meet one or more of these requirements, such as lacking the necessary hardware support or running an incompatible Windows version or edition. Devices 2, 3, and 4 satisfy both the hardware and software criteria, making them eligible for a seamless upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise.

I am not convinced you can do an in place upgrade from Windows 10 Pro to 11 Enterprise in just one step, I would think that this would need then an edition upgrade via a policy. It's hard to find the right answer
What edition of Windows 11 will I get when I upgrade?

What I found:
The upgrade to Windows 11 is for the same edition as you have on your Windows 10 device. Devices with Windows 10 Pro installed will be upgraded to Windows 11 Pro. Devices running Windows 10 Enterprise will upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise. Windows 11 Pro will not offer Windows 11 Pro in S mode, so you will need to switch out of S mode to upgrade.

comments.content: You cannot do in-place upgrade from 32-bit to 64-bit due to HAL. Only full/clean install can do that if the architecture supports it.

Selected Answer: D
To review the startup times and restart frequencies of the devices managed by Microsoft Intune, you should use:

D. Endpoint analytics

Endpoint analytics provides insights into the health and performance of your devices, including startup performance and restart frequencies.
Answer D

Selected Answer: D
Endpoint analytics aims to improve user productivity and reduce IT support costs by providing insights into the performance of the hardware and software in your organization. Specifically, it can help you review startup times and restart frequencies of devices managed through Microsoft Intune. Endpoint analytics is part of Microsoft Intune and provides valuable metrics and insights about the devices you manage, including proactive remediation scripts, startup performance, and recommended software to help improve user experience and device performance.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

review the startup times and restart frequencies of the devices.
D. Endpoint analytics

D. Endpoint analytics

Selected Answer: D
Endpoint analytics is a feature within Microsoft Endpoint Manager that provides insights into device performance and user experience. It can help you analyze startup times, shutdown times, and restart frequencies of devices. This tool allows you to identify issues affecting device performance and take actions to improve the user experience.

I believe that this should answer the question: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-11

So many wrong answers from people who might not even know the concepts or have never worked with Intune. 
The correct answer is "nothing will happen". The devices are "domain joined". You don't need to analyze anything else as devices need to be hybrid joined or AAD joined for the activation to work. Nothing will happen on a domain joined machine.

comments.content: says syncs up to Azure AD.

discussion.content:
When User1 next signs in to the devices after being assigned a Windows 11 Enterprise E5 license, the following will occur:

Device1 (Windows 10 Pro): Will activate as Windows 11 Enterprise.
Device2 (Windows 11 Pro): Will activate as Windows 11 Enterprise.
Assigning the Windows 11 Enterprise E5 license will upgrade the devices to the Enterprise edition if they are running a compatible version of Windows. Since both Device1 and Device2 are running Pro editions, they will activate as Windows 11 Enterprise upon the next sign-in.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-10
The device is Microsoft Entra joined, for example from the Access work or school pane in the Settings app that can be found under Settings > Accounts > Access work or school.

Windows Enterprise is assigned to a user, for example through the Microsoft 365 admin center. When a licensed user signs in to a device that meets requirements using their Microsoft Entra credentials, Windows steps up from Pro edition to Enterprise, or from Pro Education to Education. Once the edition is stepped up, Enterprise/Education features are unlocked. When a user's subscription expires or is transferred to another user, the device reverts seamlessly to Windows Pro or Windows Pro Education edition, once the current subscription validity expires.
Same text for both win 10 and win 11 versions of page

Device2: Will activate as Windows 11 Enterprise

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

Your network contains an on-premises Active Directory domain named contoso.com that syncs to Azure AD.

A user named User1 uses the domain-joined devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


In the Microsoft Entra admin center, you assign a Windows 11 Enterprise E5 license to User1.

You need to identify what will occur when User1 next signs in to the devices.

What should you identify for each device? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) deployment share named Share1.

You add Windows 10 images to Share1 as shown in the following table.

//IMG//


Which images can be used in the Standard Client Task Sequence, and which images can be used in the Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence?

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence cannot use custom images.

comments.content:
1. Standard Client Task Sequence: Image1, Image2, Image3, Image4, and Image5
Explanation: A Standard Client Task Sequence in MDT can use both default Windows images (like Image1, Image2, and Image3) and custom images (like Image4 and Image5). The Task Sequence installs the selected operating system image regardless of whether it is a default or custom WIM file.
2. Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence: Image1, Image2, and Image3 only
Explanation: A Standard Client Upgrade Task Sequence is designed for upgrading an existing operating system to a new version. It can only use default images from the installation media (like Image1, Image2, and Image3) because they include the necessary upgrade components. Custom images (like Image4 and Image5) lack these components and cannot be used for an in-place upgrade.

discussion.content:
BOX1: image1-2-3-4-5
BOX2: image 1-2-3
2nd answer is incorrect, you can't use custom images in standard client upgrade task sequences, so it would in fact be 1,2,3.
